entry.title: SAP Community Stammtisch Berlin ‚Äì Christmas Edition
entry.content:
SAP Community Stammtisch Berlin ‚Äì Christmas Edition
Christmas Market at Gendarmenmarkt | 16 December 2025 | 6:00 p.m.

Hard to believe, but our unforgettable pre-TechEd Stammtisch kickoff at Hofbr√§uhaus was almost a month ago already. And we‚Äôre already heading into the next round ‚Äì this time in a very different atmosphere: the smell of mulled wine instead of wheat beer, festive lights instead of beer hall lighting.

We warmly invite you to a year-end SAP Community Stammtisch at the Christmas market at Gendarmenmarkt:

  • Meeting time: 6:00 p.m.
  • Where: In front of the entrance number 2 to the Christmas market at Gendarmenmarkt 
  • Who: SAP experts and anyone who‚Äôs in the mood for exchange & networking

What to expect:

  • Networking ‚Äì meet people, catch up with familiar faces, and make new connections
  • TechEd review ‚Äì what were your personal highlights of SAP TechEd 2025? What ideas are you taking into 2026 as inspiration?
  • Professional exchange in a relaxed setting ‚Äì from S/4HANA and BTP to Analytics, anything can be on the table

Feel free to bring colleagues or community buddies ‚Äì the more diverse the group, the more interesting the conversations. Our last meetup showed once again how many exciting people are part of the Berlin SAP Community.

In a nutshell ‚Äì event details

  • Date: Tuesday, 16 December 2025
  • Time: from 6:00 p.m.
  • Location: Christmas market at Berlin Gendarmenmarkt
  • Focus: SAP Community, exchange, networking
  • Expenses are paid by each individual

If you‚Äôd like to join, please register briefly so we can plan the group size.

We‚Äôre looking forward to wrapping up the year with the SAP Community in Berlin ‚Äì see you on 16 December! üéÑ

Weihnachtsmarkt Gendarmenmarkt | 16.12.2025 | 18:00 Uhr

Kaum zu glauben, aber unser unvergesslicher Vorabend-Stammtisch zum Kickoff der SAP TechEd im Hofbr√§uhaus ist schon fast wieder einen Monat her. Und schon geht‚Äôs direkt in die n√§chste Runde ‚Äì diesmal in etwas anderer Atmosph√§re: Der Duft von Gl√ºhwein statt Wei√übier, Lichterglanz statt Brauhausbeleuchtung.

Wir laden dich herzlich ein zu einem Stammtisch zum Jahresausklang auf dem Weihnachtsmarkt am Gendarmenmarkt:

  • Treffpunkt: 18:00 Uhr
  • Ort: Vor dem Eingang 2 zum Weihnachtsmarkt am Gendarmenmarkt 

     

  • Wer: SAP Expert:innen & alle, die Lust auf Austausch haben

Was dich erwartet:

  • Networking ‚Äì einfach ins Gespr√§ch kommen, Leute wiedersehen, neue Kontakte kn√ºpfen
  • TechEd Review ‚Äì was waren deine pers√∂nlichen Highlights der SAP TechEd 2025? Was nimmst du dir f√ºr das Jahr 2026 als Inspiration mit?
  • Fachlicher Austausch in entspannter Umgebung ‚Äì von S/4HANA √ºber BTP bis Analytics, alles kann Thema sein

Bring gerne Kolleg:innen oder Community-Buddies mit ‚Äì je bunter die Runde, desto spannender die Gespr√§che. Dass die Berliner SAP Community voll mit spannenden Menschen ist, haben wir bei unserem letzten Stammtisch gesehen.

entry.title: New in Customer Insights Dashboard: Learning Section
entry.content:
The Customer Insights Dashboard (CID) has been enhanced with a new Learning section, giving SAP customers deeper visibility into their enablement activities with the SAP Enterprise Support Academy.

This addition provides an easy way to understand how your organization is engaging with the enablement offerings available in the SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support ‚Äî all within the CID view you already use for consumption and adoption insights.

What You‚Äôll Find in the Learning Tab

The new Learning section provides insights into your organization‚Äôs learning activities and engagement trends across a wide range of enablement assets, including:

  • Expert-guided Implementations (EGIs)
  • Meet-the-Expert (MTE)
  • Learning Programs
  • E-learnings

(Note: Best Practice Documents and Tutorials are no longer actively offered but may still appear in historical consumption data.)

 

You can access the new view directly from the SAP Enterprise Support Academy card in the Summary tab in CID, which displays key learning KPIs such as:

  • Total learning activities ‚Äì covering access, enrollment, and completion events
  • Distinct learning assets ‚Äì unique assets consumed by your organization
  • Assigned learning programs ‚Äì number of assigned learning program

 

Explore Your Learning Data

The Learning tab offers several interactive charts and tables to help analyze learning engagement:

  • By Deployment Model - See consumption patterns by deployment type ‚Äî Cloud, onPremise, or Cloud_and_onPrem (hybrid). Each asset is tagged according to its deployment model, helping you understand which enablement areas your organization focuses on.
  • By Delivery Method - Get an overview of consumed enablement assets by delivery format, such as EGI, MTE, or E-learning. Each delivery type is color-coded by deployment model for quick comparison.
  • Top 10 Consumed Learning Assets - Easily identify your most popular enablement topics, including the number of learning activities and their delivery formats.
  • Detailed Table View - Access detailed records of learning activities in a tabular format. Use the settings () icon to customize columns, apply filters, or group results according to your needs. 

  • Data Coverage - The learning data model includes activities from the current year plus the previous two full years, ensuring a comprehensive view of your enablement engagement over time.

 

Why It Matters

With the Learning section, you can better understand how your teams are leveraging SAP Enterprise Support enablement offerings:

  • Track consumption in key learning assets
  • Identify training trends and gaps
  • Measure engagement across solutions and deployment models

This insight supports a data-driven approach to enablement planning and ensures that your organization continues to make the most of SAP Enterprise Support Academy resources.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì Error when creating billing do...
entry.content:
Hello @LDB 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details

Posting Periods, Financial Closing, Preliminary Billing Documents, Setting Posting Dates, Date Validations

That error is caused by your FI posting period control and not by billing configuration. Billing documents adopt the billing date as the posting date and in your tenant the future period (December 2025) is not opened in SSCUI 102001. Therefore, the system requires a date earlier than 28.11.2025.

You can resolve the issue by opening the corresponding future posting period. After the period is open, the system will accept your future billing dates.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Is Intercompany Asset Transfer Across Different Count...
entry.content:
Dear @Aanchal,

That error is effectively SAP telling you this scenario is not supported by design in SAP Public Cloud. The standard Post Transfer app explicitly requires that the source and target company codes belong to the same country/region.

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('ABT1L')/S35

 

  • SAP Help Portal documentation for the Transactions family states the prerequisite: ‚ÄúThe company code of the target asset is within the same country or region‚Äù

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3e5fcf2c768746049b5627bd5a42f720/f0a16409fbc649b896add04c1c0a624e.html

So if company codes XXXX and YYYY are assigned to different countries/regions, the backend check raises FAA_POST303 and there isn‚Äôt a missing note to apply in Public Cloud to enable it this is a functional restriction of the delivered process

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: TDS Limit in SAP Based on total invoice amount for fiscal year done.
entry.content:
Hi Team,

I got a requirment from business which is i got find to done with customization with the help of enhancement,

Purpose / Objective:

The purpose of this Business requirment implementing a TDS (Tax Deducted at Source) threshold limit configuration in SAP.
Currently, the system deducts TDS on every invoice amount without checking the cumulative transaction value for each vendor at PAN.

This leads to incorrect or non-compliant deductions.

The objective of this development is to ensure that TDS is deducted only after the total transaction value for a PAN exceeds the statutory threshold limit (‚Çπ50,00,000) within a financial year.

Business Requirement

TDS should be deducted only when the cumulative invoice/payment value for a vendor PAN in a financial year exceeds ‚Çπ50,00,000.
The system must check the total amount posted for each vendor PAN from the start of the fiscal year (April) and apply TDS only when the threshold is crossed.

 

Functional Requirements:

 

TABLE

Description

INPUT Logic.

FIELD

OUTPUT                               

LFA1

Fetch Vendor by Vendor PAN detail.

Vendor PAN

J_1IPANNO

Vendor Code of same PAN

LFBW

Pass Vendor Code and get the vendor with withholding tax type 194Q-4Q

Vendor Code which I got from LFA1(J_1IPANNO)

WITHT

Vendor Details which only have TDS type 194Q-4Q

As a Functional i have created the logic but i am confuged with from which table i can pick vendor invoice amount( which is final net amount after all kind of case which can reduce vendor invoice line item except vendor payment) I triend with BSEG, But BSEG is very big table, It will not work with BSEG. Please help me with the other solution other than BSEG, I avoid BSEG here, If only BSEG help here please give a clear logic. But provide any other solution.

Can we do this by Configuration level, According to me its cannot possible because at config level its just set the invoice base amount for tds deduction but validation required on cummulative vendors at PAN level also

entry.title: Re: Function Import - The specified HTTP method is not allowed for the resource identified by the Da
entry.content:
Hi together,

This behavior is actually by design in SAP Gateway for OData V2. When you create a Function Import in SEGW and assign the HTTP method POST, the return type cannot be a collection (0..n). It must be either None, Single Entity (1), or Nullable (0..1).

The reason is that POST is intended for operations that create or modify resources, and the OData V2 specification does not allow a POST Function Import to return multiple entities. If you try to define a return type with multiplicity 0..n, the framework will reject it, and you may encounter errors like:

{
  "fault": {
    "faultstring": "Received 405 Response without Allow Header",
    "detail": {
      "errorcode": "protocol.http.Response405WithoutAllowHeader"
    }
  }
}

Solution: Return cardianlity: 1 or 0..1


This is a limitation of the OData V2 protocol and the SAP Gateway implementation, not a bug.

entry.title: How the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM Roadmap Answers Your Top 5 Transition Questions
entry.content:
Are you nervous when trying something new? I certainly am. No matter if we are talking about something simple like a new type of food, something more complex like a new travel destination, or even something that is going to impact my day-to-day life, like a new tool. What I do to try to minimize this feeling and really enjoy the experience is to research it and see what others are thinking and saying about it. 

With that in mind, I want to help you enjoy your move from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM by answering 5 frequently asked transition questions and showing you how to use the SAP Activate for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM roadmap to your advantage. 

1. How do we assess our readiness and plan our transition project using the roadmap? 

The first thing that may pop into your mind is whether you are ready to make this move, given the capabilities you already use. To help with this, we recommend you the task Perform SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM, as this will allow you to track the capabilities you are currently using in the SAP Solution Manager system, check if there are equivalent ones in SAP Cloud ALM, create possible actions plans for the functionalities that are not available, and identify other useful capabilities SAP Cloud ALM offers. 

Once you have this information, you will be able to do your Transition Planning and define if you need to do one or multiple projects based on your needs and what the next steps are. The different project types are: SAP‚ÄØCloud ALM for Operations, SAP Cloud ALM for fast-paced cloud implementations, and Transition of existing ALM processes from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM, and you can find additional information about them in the deliverable Transition Planning and subsequent tasks. 

 Additional materials: 

  • Section ‚ÄòFunctional comparison ‚Äì what goes where?‚Äô in the website Transition to SAP Cloud ALM  
  • Details about SAP Readiness Check can be found in the blog Availability of SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM and in the SAP Note 3236443 - SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM 

 2. Which ALM functions should we move first ‚Äî operations or implementation? 

This decision depends on the challenges you are facing, the scope you determined in your SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM and the goals you want to achieve. The Transition to SAP Cloud ALM roadmap does not enforce one path, but provides you with resources to analyze your current landscape, decide based on your business needs and then guide your steps along the way. 

A generic approach indicated in the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM website, under the section ‚ÄòTransition steps and recommended sequence‚Äô would be to start with the SAP Cloud ALM Operations to gain visibility into system health and monitoring; afterwards, adopt SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation so you can move at your own pace and also complement your implementation of other SAP Cloud solutions within your landscape; and lastly, add SAP Focus Run for advanced operations use cases, if necessary. 

Additional materials: 

  • Task Request SAP Cloud ALM Tenant 
  • Task Self-Enable on SAP Cloud ALM 
  • Accelerator SAP Cloud ALM ‚Äì Functional Overview 

 3. Can we run SAP Solution Manager and SAP Cloud ALM in parallel (hybrid)? 

You can run both systems in parallel during the transition phase, as this will allow you to get to know SAP Cloud ALM, respect your business needs, and ensure a smooth migration. The important thing in this process is to understand the readiness of your system, plan your transition (Transition Planning deliverable), set your priorities (task Define Implementation Strategy), and define responsibilities (Project Initiation and Governance deliverable).  

 4. What data and documents can we migrate from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM ‚Äî and when? 

The data and documents migration plan is established by you since the Prepare phase of your project, with the deliverable Data Migration Approach and Plan and subsequent tasks, when you will define the scope of this migration, estimate requirements, assign roles and responsibilities, and communicate with the relevant stakeholders. Besides that, we also have the Perform SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM task in the Prepare phase, that will provide you with insights into the assets created in the SAP Solution Manager, such as processes, documents, and test cases, that may be relevant for Selective Data Transfer. 

In the Explore phase, you will refine this plan during the Fit-to-Standard Workshops and Data Load Preparation deliverable activities, so you are able to perform your migration smoothly when you come to the task Execute Data Migration in the Realize phase. 

5. How can we upskill and prepare our team for the transition to SAP Cloud ALM? 

That is a valid concern! A transition to a new tool requires more than data analysis; we need people ready and confident to meet this new demand. The Transition to Cloud ALM roadmap takes this into account and provides you with several opportunities throughout the project‚Äôs phases to prepare your team. 

Right at the beginning, we have the deliverable Request Initial System Access that will help you gain and provide access to SAP Cloud ALM. Afterwards, with the intention of enabling your team to learn about SAP Cloud ALM and its different elements, we have the deliverable Customer Team Self-Enablement and the tasks underneath it, providing you with different steps and accelerators like the SAP Cloud ALM Learning Portal, for example. 

Besides that, we also recommend you check the tasks Establish Project Governance, Set Up Project Team Logistics and Infrastructure, and Prepare Project Team Onboarding, which will help you build your team and assign roles and responsibilities, as well as provide all the needed tools for your stakeholders to act during the project. 

 ---

Whether you‚Äôre already using SAP Cloud ALM or just exploring the first steps for this transition, the end goal is the same: have a guided path to help you have more confidence and simplicity in your day-to-day. The SAP Activate for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM roadmap is not just a timeline, but a decision-support tool to help you choose your path, assess your status, and plan your next steps. 

I hope this blog was able to help you address a few of the top-of-mind questions and how the SAP Activate Transition to Cloud ALM roadmap can help with them. Do you have other questions or suggestions about this roadmap? Leave a comment below or provide feedback in Road Map Viewer. We will be happy to help!

entry.content:
Hi there,

I'm not sure if this has been a common thread, but since the credential method change with S-ID's I've consistently had issues with signing into my various accounts. My solve has been to "forget password", which will work sometimes but other times, access to various systems is met with the same issue, even after changing passwords. In general, this approach has been inconsistent and seems unnecessary. 

In general, I've found this change to be far less efficient than the old approach, where I could use my S-ID and select the system I wanted to interact with.

entry.title: How to activate the Object Store in SAP Datasphere?
entry.content:
**Updated December 2025**

Symptom: You want to activate Object Store in SAP Datasphere, but you don't know how. 

Highlights:

  • You can create up to five spaces using the Object Store option.
  • Depending on your system, Object Store may take up to 1h to be available.
  • The deployment time for creating a file space can take some time (up to 45 min).
  • There is currently no ability to enable Object Store for existing spaces; you need to create a new one, named file space.
  • Downsizing SAP HANA Storage is not possible. It is only viable via deletion and recreation of your SAP Datasphere tenant.
  • There is no limitation regarding data center and region availability for Object Store: it is available in all data centers that SAP Datasphere is available on.  

Requirements:

  • Ensure you have at least 4151 Capacity Units (CU) for the tenant. For more information, click here.
  • Confirm that you are the system owner or have the DW Cloud Administrator role assigned to proceed with this action.
  • Make sure your SAP Datasphere tenant is on version 2021.03 or later. 

Resolution: 

1. Open your SAP Datasphere, log in, and open the navigation bar. 

2. Select "System", then click "Configuration". 

3. Go to the "Tenant Configuration" tab. 

4. In the "Base Configuration" card, select "Memory" for Performance Class. 

5. Increase Memory to 128GB and Storage to 384GB. 

6. In the ‚ÄúObject Store‚Äù card, set Storage to 1 GB, Compute to 1 Block-Hour, and Requests to 1,000 API Calls. If you need additional resources, feel free to adjust the Storage, Compute, and Requests values as needed.

7. Click "Save". 

8. Press "OK" if you agree with all statements regarding this upgrade. 

9. Wait 1h until Object Store is available. 

10. Go to "Space Management" and hit "Create".

11. Select "SAP HANA Data Lake Files" in Storage Type and press "Create". 

12. Now you have a space with Object Store enabled. 

Image 01

Image 2

Image 06

Image 07

  • 3538038 - Important considerations for SAP Datasphere object store
  • 3224686 - How to scale down your SAP Datasphere tenant

entry.title: Re: How to Calculate VAT for PO and get in the Standard f...
entry.content:
Good day @Yathurshika_Sathiyavarman 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details

Form Templates, Key User Extensibility, CDS Views for Purchase Orders, Enable Custom Fields in the Purchasing Process, App Extensibility: Create Purchase Order via Purchase Requisition Assignment List

To summarise, in public cloud, the MMM_PUR_PURCHASE_ORDER PO form Template does not expose VAT for each item because SAP does not include pricing conditions in the standard data source. You can extend the form by using a Custom CDS View that is based on API I_PurchaseOrderItemAPI01, then expose the tax fields through a Form Data Source Extension and bind them in the Adobe form. Your VAT summation and gross calculation must happen in XDP form logic.

 

Go to the Custom CDS Views app

Create a new one.

Choose I_PurchaseOrderItemAPI01 as your primary data source. (For reference purposes I used a phrase from your topic in the following screens)

In your Elements tab, click Add and choose elements

A new window opens choose as displayed and OK.

Choose the paths (e.g., PurchaseOrder, PurchaseOderItem, etc.) you require.

Then publish

Next you need to extend the PO Form Data Source. Go to Maintain Form Template Data Source Extensions. Select MM_PUR_PO_OUTPUT, click Create Extension, add your Custom CDS View as an extension node: (Node name: ZPO_ITEM_TAX) and join PurchaseOrder + PurchaseOderItem. Then publish.

Thereafter, go to Manage Form Templates app, Copy MM_PUR_PURCHASE_ORDER, download PDF, add fields under the item node: VAT per item, Net amount, Gross amount.

Next is to add your VAT summation in Adobe. Finally upload and activate your modified template back into Manage Form Templates and assign it to your MM_PUR_PO_OUTPUT and Channel.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Global account cost centre sync issue
entry.content:
Hi All, 

We have created Global account "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2" under cost centre 101830049. In recent days, for testing provisioning flow, we changed it to 101039103. 

It causing issue with tenant creation via URM. We raised a ticket to UCL team - https://jira.tools.sap/browse/NGPBUG-467218

They responded stated that cost centre change has not synced properly.

UCL stores global accounts based on events from the CIS service. 

Most of the events we received for the global account: "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2" contain the correct cost center: "101039103"

However, there are 5-6 events that contain the wrong cost center (101830049) for the mentioned global account.

Example:

{
			"id": 86951888,
			"actionTime": 1762421251765,
			"creationTime": 1762421253194,
			"details": {

				"displayName": "pdptest",
				"subdomain": "pdptest",
				"customerId": null,
				"expiryDate": null,
				"commercialModel": "Subscription",
				"costCenter": "101830049",
				"costObjectType": "COST_CENTER",
				"costObjectId": "101830049",
				"geoAccess": "STANDARD",
				"licenseType": "DEVELOPER",
				"renewalDate": null,
				"serviceId": null,
				"crmTenantId": null,
				"useFor": "Development"
			},
			"globalAccountGUID": "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2",
			"entityId": "def19557-89f7-4fee-b33e-9c26d1a9acd2",
			"entityType": "GlobalAccount",
			"eventOrigin": "accounts-service",
			"eventType": "GlobalAccount_Update"
		},

This leads to the override of the correct cost center.

Can you help us in resolving the issue. 

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Re: No edocument created in ecockpit (SAP Public Cloud)
entry.content:
Hi Janarthan,

I don't have personal experience with this but did some research (Joule for Consultants) and sharing it on - alot seems rooted around the guidance from this blog as a starting point t validate proper setup:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/electronic-invoicing-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/ba-p/13578774

and I would guess you've already browsed the Belguin HELP documentation? https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/fba518519f834ed99011786d831ee504/2f9ab027fadc4a52bd2316d3b7e45223.html

These were the joule recommendations though:

Primary Diagnostic Steps

1. Check eDocument Cockpit Status Since you cannot access tables directly in Public Cloud, use the eDocument Cockpit or Manage Electronic Documents app to check the document processing status. Look for any error messages in both the application log (content issues) and interface log (integration issues) - Tobias' blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/electronic-invoicing-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/ba-p/13578774

2. Verify Belgium-Specific Configuration The Belgium eDocument implementation requires multiple configuration steps that must be properly implemented [2]. Key areas to verify include:

  • Scope Item Activation: Ensure scope item 5XU (SAP Document and Reporting Compliance) is activated in your system [1]
  • Feature Activation: Activate Document and Reporting Compliance Features through Central Business Configuration (CBC) or Solution Builder [1]
  • Party ID Type Assignment: Confirm your Belgium company code is properly assigned to the BE:VAT party ID type
  • Business Partner Configuration: Verify the customer's Belgium VAT number is correctly assigned as a party ID type [1]
  • eDocument Type Mapping: Check that your billing document type is properly mapped to the Belgium eDocument type (BE_INV for invoices, BE_CRE for credit memos)

3. Configuration Activities Review Navigate through the following configuration sections [1]:

  • General Settings for eDocument: Review all general eDocument configuration activities
  • Belgium-Specific Configuration: Check country-specific settings for Belgium electronic documents

Common Root Causes in Public Cloud

1. Value Mappings Issues Most eDocument submission errors in Public Cloud relate to missing value mappings [1]. Use the Configure Value Mapping app to verify:

  • Navigate to the Belgium namespace
  • Check all required value mapping tables are properly maintained
  • Note that value mappings are not transported and must be maintained separately in each system [1]

2. Master Data Requirements Verify required master data attributes on :

  • Business Partner: Belgium VAT number properly maintained in identification tab
  • Product Master: Required classification codes for Belgium

3. Integration Setup For Belgium, you typically integrate with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition or a third-party provider. Verify:

  • Communication arrangements are properly configured
  • Integration flows are active and functioning
  • Service connectivity is established

Troubleshooting Process

  1. Review eDocument Cockpit: Check for any processing errors or status indicators
  2. Validate Configuration: Use the configuration activities to verify all Belgium-specific settings
  3. Check Value Mappings: Ensure all required mappings are maintained for Belgium
  4. Verify Master Data: Confirm VAT numbers and other required data are properly maintained
  5. Test Integration: Verify the connection to your eDocument service provider

If you've reviewed those sources and it's sitll not resolved, I'd recommend a ticket on component FI-LOC-CA-BE

entry.title: Re: ADBC: sending input parameter error
entry.content:
The error occurs because the Calculation View parameter is being passed as a column reference instead of a literal value. input parameters must be supplied via PLACEHOLDER with a quoted literal, for example:

 
(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => '{ p_land1 }')

After correcting the SQL string and quoting the parameter, the view executes without error.

Replace your SQL string v_str = SELECT * FROM.........(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => '{ p_land1 }') .

Debug step will show
(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => 'IN')

entry.title: Don't Wait for SAP: Unlocking MCP Servers in BAS Right Now
entry.content:
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is currently one of the hottest topics in development, promising to accelerate workflows, especially in the SAP ecosystem. Many IDEs already support MCP servers, offering developers enhanced context and capabilities.

Unfortunately, in SAP Business Application Studio (a.k.a. SAP Build Code), you are currently limited to Joule. This is particularly frustrating given that MCP servers were heavily promoted at SAP TechEd, yet the native environment doesn't fully support them yet. This limitation is especially challenging if you are restricted to using BAS because local development with tools like VS Code is not allowed or possible in your corporate environment

In this blog post, I want to show you how to not only use MCP servers directly within BAS but also explore ways to develop with BAS from the "outside" using hybrid approaches.

What are MCP Servers?

MCP servers provide the LLM client (like Claude, Cursor, or Copilot) with more context about your project and system, helping the developer work more effectively. Fortunately, there are already numerous MCP servers available for SAP.

You can learn more about the available SAP MCP servers in this blog post: SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers to enable age... - SAP Community

What Can You Do Directly in BAS?

SAP Business Application Studio is based on the Open VS Code stack (Code-OSS), which allows us to install extensions from the Open VSX Registry. Even if an extension isn't available there, you can often install the VSIX file directly. Since BAS runs in a small virtual machine, we also have the ability to install CLI tools.

Cline Extension

The first option is using the open-source extension Cline. This is also explained in the SAP Architecture Center on how to use Cline with SAP AI Core and in a TechEd Hands-on Exercise.

This extension gives you a coding agent directly within BAS that can not only answer questions but also modify code. Crucially, Cline supports MCP servers. You can install it easily via the Extensions Marketplace in BAS:

Once the SAP MCP servers are installed globally (e.g., via npm install -g sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server), we can configure them in Cline. Below is my configuration example. The command points to the local node installation. You can find the exact path using the command node -p "process.execPath". To find the location of the MCP server, you can run:

echo "$(npm root -g)/@sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server"

This configuration is saved in the cline_mcp_settings.json file, which you can access via "Configure MCP Server" in Cline's settings.

Here is my MCP config file:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "ui5-mcp": {
      "disabled": false,
      "timeout": 60,
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "/home/user/.asdf-inst/installs/nodejs/22.13.1/bin/node",
      "args": [
        "/home/user/.node_modules_global/lib/node_modules/@ui5/mcp-server/bin/ui5mcp.js"
      ]
    },
    "fiori-mcp": {
      "disabled": false,
      "timeout": 60,
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "/home/user/.asdf-inst/installs/nodejs/22.13.1/bin/node",
      "args": [
        "/home/user/.node_modules_global/lib/node_modules/@sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server/dist/index.js"
      ],
      "autoApprove": [
        "execute_functionality"
      ]
    },
    "cap-mcp": {
      "disabled": false,
      "timeout": 60,
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "/home/user/.asdf-inst/installs/nodejs/22.13.1/bin/node",
      "args": [
        "/home/user/.node_modules_global/lib/node_modules/@cap-js/mcp-server/index.js"
      ]
    }
  }
}

 

Cline allows you to flexibly use different models, including OpenAI, Anthropic, and SAP AI Core.

In this example, I want to disable the "Initial Load" of a Fiori Elements app. The Fiori Tools MCP Server supports this functionality. Even without explicitly telling the LLM client to use the MCP server, it automatically calls the appropriate tool to perform the action.

This is a great option to get started quickly and use various models and providers. However, in my experience, it can be quite slow compared to other LLM clients, and the overall experience is somewhat limited by being "just" an extension.

Claude Code

Many model providers and LLM clients now offer CLI alternatives. Two notable examples are Claude Code, Cursor CLI, or Gemini CLI. We can install these directly in BAS.

I'll use Claude Code as an example. The installation is straightforward:

curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.sh | bash

After installation, you need to authenticate. Once done, you can configure MCP servers. You can activate the tool simply by running claude. Once configured, you can use these MCP servers directly within your BAS terminal.

The configuration can be identical to the one used in Cline:

Here is an example using Claude Code to reactivate the Initial Load. Claude correctly utilizes the Fiori MCP Server to find the right tool and execute the change.

Outside of BAS (Hybrid/Remote)

Fortunately, we have the possibility to "break out" of the browser-based BAS and use a hybrid approach with a local IDE. SAP provides a way to do this via extensions. The documentation for this setup can be found here: Working Remotely with SAP Business Application Studio</a >.

VS Code and GitHub Copilot Chat

This approach enables us to connect a local VS Code instance via SSH to our running BAS instance.

This gives us the best of both worlds: all BAS-exclusive extensions and capabilities, plus everything VS Code offers, including GitHub Copilot Chat and MCP servers.

If you follow the documentation, you will have GitHub Copilot available in your local VS Code, capable of using the integrated MCP servers and the model of your choice. This provides not only direct code editing capabilities but also very smart autocompletion.

Here is an example with GitHub Copilot Chat and MCP Server. In this case, although I explicitly mentioned the MCP server, it seems the tools were not automatically recognized, so the model used the parameter in the manifest.json directly.

 

Cursor

Cursor is a very powerful tool with excellent integration of MCP servers. You can configure and use MCP servers directly in Cursor and use with any model together with BAS.

In theory, any Code-OSS based IDE that supports the necessary extensions can establish this connection. For those not bound to BAS, MCP servers can be configured and used directly in your own IDE, as almost every major IDE supports MCP servers by now.

Conclusion

While SAP Business Application Studio currently has some limitations regarding native MCP integration, there are several powerful workarounds. 

It will be exciting to see what support will be available in BAS in the future.
Will it be Cline, as shown in the TechEd demos, will Joule be upgraded, or will GitHub Copilot be included in BAS as announced in a TechEd session?
After the announcement at the TechEd keynote, I had actually expected a quick solution.

Fortunately, I am not currently tied to BAS, and even if I were, I could fall back on the workarounds.

entry.title: Re: It's possible to perform a reorg in all tables at the...
entry.content:
Currently, there is no available script to perform a reorg on all tables in the database at once due to the extensive time the process would require. To ensure the most efficient and effective outcome, the reorg must be executed individually on each table.

We understand that this may require more time and effort, but it is the best approach to maintain the integrity and performance of your database.

entry.title: Re: Preventing Negative Balances in Cost Centers in SAP P...
entry.content:
Hello @AlvaroFernandezMorales 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details

Cost Center Budget, Manage Cost Center Budgets, Budget Availability Control for Cost Centers, Budget Availability Control, Situation Handling, Availability Control Settings

Have a look at this Blog: How SAP Solutions Enable Stronger Controls and Compliance for Finance for more insights.

The reason why your Cost center shows negative balances is because the public cloud does not validate balances during the time you post.

You can trigger warning or errors when you enable Budget Availability Control and assign your budget with tolerance profiles. This will ensure the system triggers warning or also block your postings when you exceed the limit you defined. Alternatively, you can also consider using Situation Handling for your alerts.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Changing batch characteristics value using BAPI_OBJCL...
entry.content:
I had the same issue with BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE which fails with the error C1842, and the transaction code CJ12 permits to save the changes without apparent error.

But in fact, CJ12 actually logs the inconsistency (but doesn't prevent from saving). The inconsistency is shown in CJ12 via a button which becomes active in that case. You may click it to see the inconsistencies. I hope that MSC5N and MSC2N have the same feature to see the inconsistencies.

In my case, the inconsistency was due to a dependency between characteristic values, whose values conflicted. For instance, the value AA of characteristic C1 implies that the characteristic C2 is set to the value 01, but the values AA and 02 are assigned to these two characteristics, 01 is expected, so it conflicts with 02, hence the BAPI error C1842 "Conflict at characteristic C2: old value 00, new value 01", which means that the value 00 is assigned to C2 by the dependency defined in the characteristic C1, which conflicts with the desired value 01.

The problem is to know which characteristics and characteristic values contain these dependencies.

I don't see any tool to trace the problem with detailed information, but CJ12 offers a "list screen" of characteristics with the option to show all dependencies.

I wanted to find a way to know the dependencies by debug, unfortunately I can't find a simple way to explain it.

For now, I'm writing the key function modules, it could help someone who wants to debug. I hope I can find more time to complete the list of internal tables and the exact logic to obtain the dependencies.

BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE calls the function module CACL_OBJECT_VALIDATION_MAINT which calls 3 important function modules:

  1. CLAP_DDB_UPDATE_CLASSIFICATION:
    1. The current characteristic values are loaded from the database into the memory.
  2. CTMS_DDB_DEL_VALUE
    1. For the characteristics from BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE which can have only a single value, their values are deleted from the memory.
  3. CTMS_DDB_SET_VALUE
    1. The characteristic values from BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE are loaded into memory and their dependent characteristic values are calculated (still in memory).
    2. If one characteristic value overwrites a previously calculated value, there's a conflict.

NB: my system is S/4HANA 2023 FPS 1 ON-PREMISE.

entry.title: How to view balance confirmation history for customer/vendor in S/4HANA?

Dear everyone,

entry.title: How to provision SAP BDC Connect for Databricks?
entry.content:
**Updated December 2025**

Symptom: You want to provision SAP BDC Connect to give access to BDC data and share data products with your existing Databricks environment, but you're not sure how to proceed.

Requirements:

  • Confirm that you are a super admin or cloud admin in SAP for Me. 
  • Make sure you have already provisioned SAP BDC Cockpit.  
  • Provision SAP BDC Connect in the same region that you provisioned SAP BDC Cockpit.
  • Ensure your Databricks environment is in AWS, Azure, or Google.
  • Have a Databricks workspace with enabled Unity Catalog and Delta-Sharing. If you want more guidance, click here.  
  • Guarantee that you are a Databricks admin and have the "CREATE PROVIDER" and "CREATE RECIPIENT" privileges. For more information, click here. 

Resolution: If you want to have a video version of this process, please refer to this blog post from @eduardo_nedel. A great resource! 

1. Open SAP for Me, log in and select "Portfolio & Products".

2. Click "Business Data Cloud" in My Product Packages card.

3. Select "Applications"  tab, then "Start Provisioning" in SAP BDC Connect card. 

4. Type a name to identify the SAP BDC Connect in "Name" (you can edit it later).

5. Select the resource group where you provisioned SAP BDC cockpit in "Path", and click "Next". 

6. Assign the planned Capacity Units (CU) for SAP BDC Connect, then click ‚ÄúNext.‚Äù This quota is only a guideline, so you can exceed the usage if needed. If you‚Äôre unsure how many CUs to allocate, use the SAP BDC Estimator.

7. Open Databricks environment, log in, and select the workspace you want to work with.

8. In the navigation bar, click "Data Ingestion", then "SAP Business Data Cloud" in Databricks connectors section. 

9. Press "Connection Identifier" to copy the information from system instance identifier.

10. Return to SAP for Me and paste the information from Databricks into "External System Instance Identifier". 

11. Select the region where you provisioned SAP BDC Cockpit, then click "Next".  

12. Review your information and press "Finish". Close the pop-up. 

13. Go to "Resources", wait a few minutes (30 maximum), and you will see a notification message for your SAP BDC Connect. Click on it to check the details, then copy the link provided. 

14. Go back to Databricks environment and click "Connect to SAP BDC". 

15. Paste the URL provided in SAP for Me notification and click "Connect".

16. A green-light pop-up will appear: "Connection to SAP Business Data Cloud was successful. Data can now be shared between SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks". The process is finished. 

17. Don't forget to create a formation. For more guidance, please check this documentation. 

Image 01

 

Image 02

Image 03

Image 04

Image 05

Image 06 

Image 07

Image 08

Image 09

Image 10

Image 11

Sources:

  • Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect and Enrolling with Existing Databricks
  • Help Portal: Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect
  • Databricks: Share data between SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and Databricks
  • Databricks: Set up Delta Sharing for your account (for providers)

entry.title: Agent Mining in SAP Signavio: Understand agent behavior
entry.content:
AI agents are transforming enterprise operations‚Äîautonomously interpreting data, making decisions, and executing tasks ; but as you scale your use of AI, a new challenge emerges: how do you truly understand what your agents are doing, why they act the way they do, and what their return on investment really is?

That‚Äôs the value of the agent mining capabilities in SAP Signavio solutions ‚Äîto bring visibility, accountability, and continuous optimization to the growing ecosystem of AI-driven process transformation.

The Problem: Invisible Autonomy in Enterprise AI

As AI agents become more autonomous, their behavior may become more ambiguous. Their decisions happen in milliseconds, driven by complex reasoning or LLM-based inference that isn‚Äôt always visible to end users.

This creates critical business questions:

  •  What specific actions are my agents taking within my processes and how they are impacting them? Are they acting in compliance to my rules and policies?
  • How much does it cost to run them?
  • Are they actually delivering measurable business value?

Without transparency, organizations risk unpredictable outcomes‚Äîagents that operate efficiently on paper but unpredictably in practice, potentially introducing errors, inefficiencies, or unnecessary costs.

Discover agent mining in SAP Signavio

Agent mining enables organizations to understand and optimize the behavior of AI agents operating across their business processes. It provides the ability to:

  • Trace agent behavior: See how agents make decisions, navigate process steps, and adapt to different contexts.
  • Analyze impact: Measure the agents‚Äô influence on key metrics like process time, accuracy, and compliance.
  • Monitor cost: Track computational or LLM-related expenses to ensure cost-efficient performance.
  • Benchmark performance: Compare agent iterations to identify areas for refinement.

Agent Mining is available natively for SAP Joule Agents, but it can also extend to third-party or custom-built agents, offering a unique and unified lens across your AI landscape.

The Broader Vision: AI Agent Excellence

Agent mining is one of four pillars of our comprehensive approach to AI agent excellence, ensuring that intelligent agents operate efficiently with the necessary process context while being safely adopted in full compliance and governance.

  1. Agent discovery ‚Äì Identify the right processes and opportunities where AI agents can drive the greatest impact.
  2. Agent context ‚Äì Provide agents with the right process knowledge and compliance parameters to act responsibly and efficiently.
  3. Agent mining ‚Äì Observe and analyze how agents actually behave in operation‚Äîwhat decisions they take, how they perform, and how much they cost.
  4. Agent value impact ‚Äì Quantify the business value that agents deliver, such as efficiency gains, cost savings, or improved customer experience.

Together, these pillars ensure that organizations not only build AI agents for processes but continuously learn from and improve them to ensure compliance, governance and safe adoption into enterprise organizations.

A Real-World Example: The Accounts Receivable Agent

Consider the SAP‚Äôs Accounts Receivable (AR) Agent, which automates parts of the order-to-cash cycle. This agent matches payments to open invoices, interprets remittance advice, sends reminders for overdue accounts, and escalates exceptions for human review. The agent can help produce important benefits, for example, it helps reduce Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) by prioritizing the closure of open items and surfacing high-value follow-up actions. It analyzes behavioral patterns to anticipate risk, recommend next best actions, and support users with meaningful, context-aware insights.

By leveraging the agent mining capabilities in SAP Signavio, the AR team can analyze the agent behaviour and understand why or how those results are achieved, and more specifically:

  • Observe decision patterns: Understand when the agent decides to match invoices automatically versus escalating them.
  • Identify cost drivers: Detect cases where complex remittance language triggers costly LLM inference cycles.
  • Evaluate process impact: Quantify how agent-driven automation reduces days sales outstanding (DSO) or exception-handling time.
  • Optimize agent logic: Spot recurring scenarios that lead to human overrides and refine the agent‚Äôs contextual knowledge accordingly.

For example, if the mining data shows that certain customers‚Äô remittance notes consistently confuse the agent, the team can retrain the model or adjust confidence thresholds‚Äîcutting costs and improving accuracy.

The Next Chapter: From a Single Agent to a Multi-Agent System

Building on the Accounts Receivable (AR) Agent example, we now take a step further‚Äîfrom understanding one agent‚Äôs behavior to analyzing an entire ecosystem of agents working together. In many real-world scenarios, business outcomes aren‚Äôt driven by a single autonomous agent but by a network of collaborating agents that coordinate to solve broader, cross-functional challenges.

Let‚Äôs now imagine a hypothetical scenario where the Accounts Receivable Agent operates alongside other agents such as one for order management, one for billing, and one supporting customer communication . Together in this example, they form a multi-agent system that manages the complete order-to-cash lifecycle‚Äîautomatically resolving discrepancies, predicting late payments, and even initiating proactive customer outreach.

By applying multi-agent mining within SAP Signavio, process experts such as process owners, managers and analysts can uncover not just what individual agents do, but how they interact and collectively drive business performance. This enables them to:

  • Discover collaboration dynamics: Analyze how agents exchange information or trigger actions across processes to achieve shared goals.
  • Detect coordination gaps: Identify where hand-offs between agents cause delays, redundancies, or missed insights.
  • Measure systemic impact: Evaluate how agent collaboration influences high-level KPIs such as cash flow, customer satisfaction, or process cycle time.
  • Refine orchestration rules: Optimize the logic that governs when and how agents should intervene or communicate for maximum efficiency.

For example, if mining data reveals that the agent supporting billing often waits for the  agent for accounts receivable to complete validation before sending invoices‚Äîcreating unnecessary latency‚Äîthe orchestration can be adjusted to allow parallel execution with confidence thresholds. This evolution‚Äîfrom analyzing a single agent to optimizing a network of agents‚Äîdemonstrates how agent mining at scale can transform isolated automation into an intelligent, collaborative digital workforce.

In the following demonstration, we show how multi-agent mining in SAP Signavio reveals collaboration patterns between a series of fictious agents.. By analyzing their interactions, we uncover coordination gaps, optimize orchestration, and see how their combined behavior drives end-to-end business performance.

 

Why Agent Mining Matters

Agent mining is more than a monitoring capability‚Äî It provides a new level of visibility and measurable insights empowering organizations to:

  • Increase transparency into agent behavior and decision logic.
  • Control operational costs by understanding and optimizing LLM usage.
  • Ensure compliance through auditable decision trails.
  • Continuously improve performance by learning from live agent execution.
  • Measure true business value of AI automation, not just efficiency metrics.

From Discovery to Value

Agent mining is core to maximize the impact of AI agent deployments and attain AI agent excellence. From discovering where to deploy agents, to contextualizing their operations, to measuring their impact, mining provides the visibility needed for responsible, high-performance AI agent adoption.

The result: AI agents that don‚Äôt just work‚Äîthey work transparently, efficiently, and strategically.

With SAP Signavio capabilities for agent mining, organizations can finally see, understand, and optimize the invisible intelligence powering their digital processes.

entry.title: Understanding Validity Periods in Manage Profit Centers: Operations, Limitations and Auto-Adjustment
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Purpose of Profit Center Validity Periods
  • Types of Validity Periods
  • Core Operations
  • Create
  • Update
  • Delete
  • Limitations
  • Automatic Adjustments
  • Splitting
  • Merging
  • Conclusion

Introduction

A validity period represents the timeframe during which master data is valid and can be used in business transactions. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, validity periods define when specific master data objects (such as profit centers, cost centers, or activity types) are active and applicable for postings, reporting, and planning.

Purpose of Profit Center Validity Periods

Validity periods help ensure accuracy and integrity of controlling master data by supporting:

  • Organizational changes ‚Äì maintain structure changes without losing historical records
  • Time accuracy ‚Äì ensure correct master data applies within the correct timeframe
  • Auditability ‚Äì provide a complete historical trail for compliance and audits
  • Future planning ‚Äì schedule structural changes with a future start date

Note: Key components include Valid From (start date), Valid To (end date), and Time-based fields (attributes specific to a validity period)

Types of Validity Periods

  • Active Period ‚Äì period currently used for postings
  • Future Period ‚Äì upcoming period planned in advance
  • Historical Period ‚Äì past configurations retained for reporting and audits

Core Operations

To demonstrate the basic work with validity periods within the Manage Profit Centers app, three simple cases are shown below: Create, Update, and Delete.

Create

Creating a new profit center requires completing mandatory master data fields (Profit Center, Profit Center Name, Valid From / Valid To, Person Responsible, Standard Hierarchy Node and Segment). Once the profit center is created, the system automatically generates its first validity period.

Note: When creating additional validity periods, system rules must be followed (see Limitations)

Example:

  • Valid From: 11/01/2025
  • Valid To: 12/31/2025‚ÄÉ

Create Operation

Update

A validity period already exists; however, when dates need to be adjusted (for example, extending the end date), the user can modify these fields directly in edit mode. Extending a period is always allowed if no limitations are violated.

Note: Shortening is restricted when postings exist (see Limitations)

Example:

  • Valid From: 11/01/2025
  • Valid To: 12/31/2025
  • Valid To (New): 12/31/2026

Update Operation

Delete

Although deletion is less commonly used (users are often cautious about removing master data), it is still possible to delete a validity period under strict conditions - primarily the absence of postings.

Note: If postings exist within the fiscal year, deletion is not allowed (see Limitations)

Delete Operation

Limitations

To ensure data consistency, correct reporting, and reliable controlling processes, several rules restrict how validity periods can be created, modified, or deleted. You can edit validity periods for profit centers, but the changes you're allowed to make depend on the following attributes:

Profit Center Attribute

Validity Period Rules

Multiple validity periods

  • Periods can't partially overlap. A period can be lengthened if it doesn't partially overlap another period.
  • Periods must be continuous. There can't be gaps between periods.

Cost center assignment

  • The validity period of a profit center assigned to a cost center must be equal to or longer than the validity period of the cost center.
  • Periods of profit centers assigned to cost centers can't be shortened.
Postings
  • Periods can‚Äôt be shortened or deleted if they contain a posting.
  • Periods can‚Äôt be shortened if they share a fiscal year with a posting, whether it is within that specific period or not.

Example:

SAP Help Portal - Editing Validity Periods

Automatic Adjustments

To simplify work for users and reduce manual maintenance, the system can automatically adjust validity periods when creating or updating them. These adjustments include:
  • Splitting
  • Merging

Splitting

Splitting occurs when part of an existing validity period becomes part of a new validity period. This happens when you create a new validity period that falls entirely within an existing period but contains different time-based data. If these conditions are met, the system splits the validity periods automatically when you save the new period. Splitting only occurs when two validity periods interact, not three. You cannot create a new validity period that partially overlaps two existing periods. Postings do not affect splitting.

Example:

  • Original Validity Period: 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2026
  • New Validity Period (different time-based fields): 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2025
  • Outcome:
    • Period A: 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2025
    • Period B: 01/01/2026 ‚Äì 12/31/2026

Steps to achieve Splitting:

Splitting - step 1Splitting - step 2Splitting - step 3Splitting - outcome

Note: The split can occur at the beginning, middle, or end of the original period. Partial overlaps are not allowed. The system automatically creates the resulting periods. More at SAP Help Portal.

Merging

Merging occurs when a new period and an existing period can be combined into a single period. This happens when both periods have identical time-based data and are either directly adjacent or the new period is fully contained within the existing period. If these conditions are met, the system merges the periods automatically when you save the changes. A partial overlap between two periods does not trigger merging. Postings do not affect merging.

Example:

  • Original Validity Period: 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2025
  • New Validity Period (same time-based fields): 01/01/2026 ‚Äì 12/31/2026
  • Outcome:
    • Merged Period: 11/01/2025 ‚Äì 12/31/2026

Steps to achieve Merging:

MergingMerging - outcome

Note: Merging works only if the time-dependent fields are identical. Merging applies when periods are adjacent or new is fully contained within the original one. Partial overlaps cannot be merged. More at SAP Help Portal.

Conclusion

Managing validity periods is a core part of maintaining clean, reliable, and audit-ready profit center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. By understanding how periods are created, updated, and controlled (and how the system automatically handles splitting and merging) you can ensure that organizational changes are reflected accurately without disrupting historical reporting or future planning. With these principles in place, profit center maintenance becomes more consistent, predictable, and aligned with both business and compliance needs.

entry.title: Re: How to set master recipe of process order which does...
entry.content:
In process manufacturing, the machine time for producing a product is often fixed in many scenarios. For example, in the chemical industry, the reaction time in equipment remains consistent regardless of the production quantity. Given this characteristic, we typically configure fixed machine time in the resource master data without considering the production qty.

In the resource (CRC1), you should set this Formula key  in Capacity & Schedule & costing.

An in master recipe, you should use this resource, and only maintain the machine time.

In another word, the calculation Formula  which setting in background configuration, and assign to the resource, then resource used in master recipe.

entry.title: What is the Data Retrieval Logic in a Balance Sheet/ Income StatementsÔºü
entry.content:
‰∏Ä.What is a Balance Sheet/ Income Statements?
This is a financial statement that outlines a company's financial position at a specific moment. It consists of three main components:

  1. Assets: The resources owned by a business, categorized into current assets (e.g., cash, accounts receivable, inventory) and non-current assets (e.g., buildings, machinery, intangible assets).

  2. Liabilities: The debts and obligations the company must repay, split into current liabilities (e.g., accounts payable, short-term loans) and long-term liabilities (e.g., long-term debt, bonds).

  3. Owner's Equity: Also known as shareholders' equity, it represents the residual interest in the assets of the company after deducting liabilities, typically comprising paid-in capital and retained earnings.

These elements are bound by the fundamental balance sheet equation: Assets = Liabilities + Owner‚Äôs Equity.

‰∫å.Data Retrieval Logic for "Undistributed Profits"
In the context of executing a period-end report, such as a Chinese balance sheet or profit and loss statement, understanding the data retrieval logic is essential, particularly for items like "Undistributed Profits." Users may often question the accuracy of this item, and verification can be approached systematically by examining the financial statement configuration:

  1. Configuration: "Undistributed Profits" is extracted from the retained earnings account and SAP's standard net profit nodes. Since the calculation nodes automate this process, one cannot drill down to transaction details directly from the balance sheet.

  2. Verification Process: Users should utilize tools such as "Display G/L Account Balances" to examine beginning, ending, and period transaction balances to ensure figures are accurate.

  3. Example Logic for Year-End Reports:
    As an example for executing the Chinese balance sheet/profit and loss statement for the end of 2024 and 2025, the data retrieval logic for the "Undistributed Profits" item is as follows:

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the beginning of 2024 = Retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2024 + Net profit node's beginning balance (generally, after normal year-end closing, the net profit balance has been carried forward, so the beginning balance should be 0).

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the end of 2024 = Retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + Net profit balance for the year.

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the beginning of 2025 = Retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2025 + Net profit node's beginning balance (generally, after normal year-end closing, the net profit balance has been carried forward, so the beginning balance should be 0).

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the end of 2025 = Retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + Net profit balance for the current year.

       

    • After proper year-end closing, the beginning balance for the "Undistributed Profits" item in 2025 should equal the ending balance for 2024, which means that the retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2025 = retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + net profit for the 2024 period.

Conclusion

The data retrieval logic in a balance sheet, particularly for "Undistributed Profits," involves a blend of systematic configuration and thorough verification. By meticulously following these processes, companies can ensure the accuracy of their financial disclosures, ultimately aiding in informed decision-making.

Hope the information could help you.

Best regards,

Lola

entry.title: Re: Need Help: Display Welcome Message on Hire Date in On...
entry.content:
Hello Vijay,
The Welcome Message Card or "Welcome Aboard" can be controlled to match your requirements. However, this would mean that the Welcome Message Task will have to be completed manually by the responsible user on the start date. 
If you would like to automate this, I would recommend using Custom Homepage Cards. The Custom Homepage cards can be controlled based on the start date to display the relevant information/documents.
Reference Link: Creating or Editing Custom Cards for the Home Page

entry.title: Upload a file in SAP Build apps
entry.content:
Upload a file using SAP Build apps

Hello All,

Hope you are doing well.

I am creating a web application using SAP build apps in which I want to pick file from local filesystem and pass the content of the file to a LLM configured using AI core .

I tried using the Pick Files component available in market place for achieving the upload part and was able to do so but as mentioned in the official documentation the component does not support web platform.

 

Can you guide me how I can have this functionality for web application.

Thanks & regards,

Pankaj Gupta

entry.title: Re: Activate Joule in SAP Concur - a Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Hi Nagesh,

I am adding some information on importance of domains ondemand.com and cloud.sap and their impact on the LOB's. since concur is not behaving the way other LOB's like SF and Ariba supports cloud.sap. Here is the link on how the cookies challenge in IAS can overcome by using the below option recently added into after my interaction with SAP Development and product support teams.

Sync SSO Cookie Between Domains | SAP Help Portal

Also there will be multiple challenges for those concur customers who already integrated SSO with IAS and as requirement of Joule that all the LOB's who wants to be integrated with it should be part of the IAS in which Joule is configured. By chance the Global ID is already configured in concur and Joule integrated IAS has a different Global ID then customer will be forced change the Global ID in concur in order to maintain the uniqueness.

Thanks and Regards

entry.title: Re: displaying .msg attachments
entry.content: If you would like to access .msg files, you can first check the .msg file directly within your Copy & Paste application (e.g., Outlook) via double-clicking it twice; if this doesn't work, there are several websites that offer an ability to view and access .msg files directly from a webpage (also known as "online" viewers) or in your computers native Mail program (e.g., Windows Mail, Mac Mail, etc.). Occasionally there can be an issue with .msg file corruption; in this case you would want to obtain another copy of the .msg file either by downloading it again from the sender or requesting a resend from the original sender. In instances where .msg attachments are still not displaying properly, the best option would be to utilize a proven third-party product. One such provider is Softaken MSG Converter which allows users to open, view and convert .msg emails directly into other formats such as PDF, EML, MBOX or PST without requiring Outlook. This software provides efficiency and ease of use and is simple enough to be utilized by non-technical users.

entry.title: Navigate to Custom Service UI from Mashup in SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 and SAP ESM
entry.content:
In Sales and Service Cloud V2 extensible ecosystem, seamless navigation between standard and custom UIs is vital for enhancing productivity and supporting flexible business processes. Until now, you could easily navigate from a mashup to the UIs (Details, Quick Create, Quick View, Details View) of standard entities‚Äîlike Case, Account, and others‚Äîbut not to your own custom Uis created by Admin via Custom Services setting.

Now,  Sales and Service Cloud V2  introduces support to directly navigate from mashups to custom UIs‚Äîwhether they‚Äôre generated by the platform or has mashup embedded. This blog guides you on how to achieve that, and why this is a game changer for side-by-side extensibility.

Why Is This Important?

  • Consistent User Journeys: Allow users to open custom  screens directly from anywhere your mashup is used.
  • Efficient Workflows: For customers, custom navigation means fewer screen switches and better productivity.
  • Flexible Extensibility: Supports advanced side-by-side extensibility scenarios, vital for custom innovation leveraging standard and custom solutions together.

Example Use Case

Imagine you build a "Custom Request Order" object. Your support agent works from an Account screen (standard entity) with a mashup showing quick stats. Now, with this new feature, the agent clicks a link/button in the mashup and jumps directly to the custom Service Request UI.

How To: Enable Navigation to Custom UI from Mashup

Step 1 : Create Custom Service

Create working Custom Service of any type either Mashup Based or Entity Based respectively with required UIViews ( Details, Quick Create, Quick View, Worklist).

After generating the UI, You will notice a Routing Key in Design App UI. This Routing Key uniquely identifies your custom UI in the navigation framework. Since its custom, key starts with ‚Äúcustomer.ssc‚Äù.

                                       

Tip: The Routing Key is required for navigation and note it down for future use.

Step 2 : Add Navigation Trigger in Mashup Application

With your custom service UI and its Routing Key ready, the next step is to enable users to trigger the navigation from your mashup application.

Since mashups are loaded in an IFrame in SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2, navigation must be communicated to the host application using the ‚ÄúpostMessage‚Äù mechanism. This ensures secure and reliable cross-frame communication.

Implement postMessage with Navigation Parameters

To enable SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 to recognize a navigation request from your mashup, send a structured message containing all necessary navigation details and parameters. Object Parameter structure is mentioned below:

PostMessage Parameter Structure

  • Create an object with the following structure:

{

  operation: "navigation",           // Mandatory: Identifies this as a navigation scenario

  params: {                          // Mandatory: Navigation details

    objectKey: "",                   // Mandatory((for Details/Quick View) : UUID of the custom instance

    routingKey: "",                  // Mandatory: Unique key for your UI view

    viewType: ""                     // Mandatory: Type of view to open ("list", "details", "quickcreate", "quickview")

  }

}

Example:

function openCustomRequestOrderDetails() {

  var ReqDetails = {

    operation: "navigation",

    params: {

      objectKey: "067da462-f76e-41c6-9c16-d6ec5c3494e3",   // Example UUID

      routingKey: "customer.ssc.CUSXXXX",                   // Your custom UI routing key

      viewType: "details"                                   // Target UI view: list, details, quickcreate, or quickview

    }

  };

  self.window.parent.postMessage(ReqDetails, '*');

}

Security Note:

    • In production, replace "*" with the actual origin of your SAP application for added security.
    • Ensure that only trusted messages are acted upon in the host application. 
  • Attach this function with Button Click or with any element as required. Example:

<input type='button' value='Open Custom Request' onclick= openCustomRequestOrderDetails ()/>

Step 3 : Create and Integrate Your Mashup in Sales and Service Cloud V2

Create an HTML Mashup

  • As an Administrator, navigate to Mashup Authoring setting  in Sales and Service Cloud.
  • Select Create > HTML Mashup.
  • Provide the Mashup application URL,other mandatory and required data .

                                     

 Add  Mashup in target UI

  • Go to the Adaptation menu in the target UI (for example, Case, Account, etc).
  • Add the mashup as a section or tab using the Adaptation Menu. Place your mashup where it makes the most sense for user workflow.

                                              

Save and Apply the changes.  Its done  üôÇ

 

Please find the Examples function for List View, Quick Create and Quick View respectively.

 

// Sample function to open Quick Create

function openCustomServiceCreateWithRoutingKey() {
        var oQCObject = {operation: "navigation", params: {routingKey: "customer.ssc.CUSXXXX", viewType: "quickcreate"}};
               self.window.parent.postMessage(oQCObject , '*')
            }
 
// Sample function to open Quick View
    function openCustomServiceQVWithRoutingKey() {
           var oQVObject = {operation: "navigation", params: {objectKey: "067da462-f76e-41c6-9c16-d6ec5c3494e3", routingKey: "customer.ssc.CUSXXXX", viewType: "quickview"}};
          self.window.parent.postMessage(oQVObject , '*')
     }
 
// Sample function to open List View
 function openCustomServiceListWithRoutingKey() {
       var oListObject = { operation: "navigation", params: {routingKey: "customer.ssc.CUSXXXX", viewType: "list"}};
         self.window.parent.postMessage(oListObject , '*')
                        }
